MINUTES (IN CHAMBERS) by Judge Beverly Reid O'Connell: ORDER RE DEFENDANTS' MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS PENDING DECISION ON MOTION TO TRANSFER 18 The Court GRANTS Defendants Motion. The Court hereby STAYS this Action for sixty (60) days. The parties shall submit a joint report to apprise the Court of this matters status upon either (1) the JPMLs ruling on the Transfer Motion, or (2) the expiration of the 60−day stay, whichever comes first. The hearingscheduled for June 26, 2017 is hereby VACATED.IT IS SO ORDERED. (rfi) (Entered: 06/21/2017)

special_collections: Trump Administration 1.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
On April 12, 2017, the ACLUs of Southern California and Nevada filed this suit under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). This was one of over a dozen such suits; each aimed to shed light on how U.S. Customs and Border Protection implemented President Trump's January 27 and March 6 Executive Orders (EO) that ban admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.

Specifically, plaintiffs sought information "concerning CBP’s local implementation of President Trump’s January 27, 2017 Executive Order...as well as any other judicial order or executive directive issued regarding Executive Order No. 1, including President Trump’s March 6, 2017 Executive Order." The request concerned implementation at international airports within the purview of CBP's Los Angeles Field Office, including Los Angeles International Airport and McCarran International Airport. The request also concerned the number of individuals who were detained or subjected to secondary screening, extended questioning, enforcement examination, or consideration for a waiver at the aforementioned airports pursuant to the EO.

In the complaint, the plaintiffs argued that the requested records "would facilitate the public’s understanding of how Defendants implemented and enforced the Executive Orders in the Los Angeles Field Office" and that "[s]uch information is critical to the public’s ability to hold the government accountable."

The case was assigned to Judge Beverly Reid O'Connell.

On May 8, the government filed a motion to treat all of these FOIA cases as "multidistrict litigation" effectively consolidating them before the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. For the transfer motion see this case. On May 17, the government moved to stay the proceedings pending the consolidation decision. The ACLU filed their opposition to the motion to transfer on May 30, arguing that "[g]ranting consolidation and transfer would promote forum-shopping and delay, not justice." On Jun. 21, the court ordered proceedings stayed for 60 days.

On Aug. 3, the U.S. District Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation denied the government's consolidation motion. In its order, the Panel found that, although the thirteen FOIA cases shared "a limited number of factual issues," these issues "appear[ed] relatively straightforward and unlikely to entail extensive pretrial proceedings." Following the Panel's denial, Judge O'Connell lifted the stay and litigation continued.

On Nov. 3, the case was reassigned to Judge Robert H. Whaley.

On Dec. 13, 2017, the court set a production schedule ordering the government to review and produce responsive records in monthly batches through February 2018. The government completed its production by March 2018, and after the parties conferred, the ACLU stated in an August 2018 status report that it was satisfied with the production and would not pursue further litigation. Attorneys' fees and costs are the only outstanding issue the parties are currently working to resolve.

By May 28, 2019, the parties had come to an agreement regarding attorneys' fees and costs. They therefore submitted a stipulation of dismissal on June 19, 2019, which was granted that same day. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: On April 12, 2017, the ACLUs of Southern California and Nevada filed this suit under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). This was one of over a dozen such suits; each aimed to shed light on how U.S. Customs and Border Protection implemented President Trump's January 27 and March 6 Executive Orders that ban admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. Defendants began producing documents in December of 2017 and finished the production in March of 2018. Attorneys' fees and costs were settled privately and the case is now closed.
case_data.summary_tiny: Final updates regarding @ACLU_SoCal and their FOIA requests against @CBP and @DHSgov. ACLU sued the government in 2017, demanding production of certain documents relating to enforcement of @realDonaldTrump's Muslim Ban

TRA NSFER;

SECURITY, et al.,

Defendants.  SUPP ORT

28 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings      

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 2 of 10   Page ID #:258
 
1 
BACKGROUND 
2 
In their Motion to stay the proceedings, Defendants requested that this Court 
3 
impose a brief stay of the proceedings—likely only for a matter of weeks—while 
4 
their motion to transfer this and twelve other related actions filed by ACLU 
5 
6  affiliates is pending before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation.  Plaintiffs 
7 
spend the bulk of their Opposition arguing against consolidation.  Plaintiffs 
8 
repeatedly argue that this case is unrelated to the others, Pls.’ Opp’n at 4, 10-11, 
9 
13-14 (ECF No. 20)—even though all of them were brought by ACLU affiliates as 
10 
11  admittedly “coordinated” lawsuits and even though they all concern parallel FOIA 
12 
requests for identical or nearly identical categories of records, see Transfer Mot. at 
13 
4-7 (ECF No. 15-3)—because the plaintiffs are different ACLU affiliates and 
14 
because the requests seek records from different CBP field offices.  Such 
15 
arguments should instead be addressed to the JPML, which is considering whether 
16 
17  consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings would be appropriate (and which 
18 
has previously centralized FOIA actions over similar objections).   
19 
  As Defendants have explained, a temporary stay of proceedings until the 
20 
JPML can decide Defendants’ motion to transfer serves the interests of judicial 
21 
22  economy and avoids any significant burden to either party.  The JPML is likely to 
23  hear and decide the transfer motion only a few weeks after the first deadline in this 
24 
case.  Any stay of this duration would have no effect on the timing of Defendants’ 
25 
release of responsive records, and thus Plaintiffs will suffer no prejudice.  
26 
Moreover, the strategic behavior of Plaintiffs and the other ACLU affiliates in 
27 
28  unnecessarily bringing the related actions as thirteen separate cases obviously 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 1 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 3 of 10   Page ID #:259
 
1 
imposes a burden on Defendants from having to engage in parallel proceedings in 
2 
thirteen courts.  And Plaintiffs have not explained why this Court should now 
3 
expend its resources on pretrial proceedings—including status reports, scheduling 
4 
orders, and possible discovery—when those issues would need to be re-litigated 
5 
6  before the transferee court. 
7 
  Stays pending a JPML motion, while not automatic, are routine.  See, 
8 
e.g., Defs.’ Mot. at 2-3 (ECF No. 18) (collecting authorities); see also, e.g., San 
9 
Diego Unified Port Dist. v. Monsanto Co., No. 15-cv-00578-WQH-JLB, 2016 WL 
10 
11  4496826, at *1 (S.D. Cal. Feb. 1, 2016) (“majority of courts have concluded that it 
12 
is often appropriate to stay preliminary pretrial proceedings”); Automated 
13 
Transactions, LLC v. Bath Sav. Inst., No. 2:12-cv-393-JAW, 2013 WL 1346470, at 
14 
*2 (D. Me. Mar. 14, 2013) (courts grant stays “frequently”); Bonenfant v. R.J. 
15 
Reynolds Tobacco Co., No. 07-60301-CIV, 2007 WL 2409980, at *1 (S.D. Fla. 
16 
17  July 31, 2007) (“common practice” to grant stays).1  Contrary to Plaintiffs’ 
18                                              
1 Plaintiffs erroneously suggest that “courts frequently deny” stays pending a 
19 
JPML decision on a motion to transfer.  Pls.’ Opp’n at 12-13.  The cases they cite 
20 
for this proposition are easily distinguishable, and, in any event, are against the clear 
21  weight of authority recognizing that stays in this context are routine.  See Sehler v. 
Prospect Mortg., LLC, No. 1:13cv473(JCC/TRJ), 2013 WL 5184216, at *3 (E.D. 
22 
Va. Sept. 16, 2013) (denying stay where defendant agreed to decertification of class 
23  before  moving  for consolidation before  the JPML  and  where  stay  would have 
delayed case by four to six months, during which time trial would occur); Sullivan 
24 
v. Cottrell, Inc., No. 11CV1076S, 2012 WL 694825, at *5 (W.D.N.Y. Feb. 29, 2012) 
25  (holding that stay was not warranted where motion to remand raised issues regarding 
court’s jurisdiction and where court could decide remand motion and motion to 
26 
dismiss before the JPML heard transfer motion); St. Joe Co. v. Transocean Offshore 
27 
Deepwater Drilling Inc., 774 F. Supp. 2d 596, 600-02 (D. Del. 2011) (denying stay 
28 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 2 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 4 of 10   Page ID #:260
 
1 
contention, there is no exception to the typical practice when the government seeks 
2 
transfer of FOIA cases.  Indeed, as discussed below, stays pending a decision of 
3 
the JPML have been granted in numerous FOIA cases.  In light of the limited 
4 
duration of any potential stay here, the ACLU affiliates’ strategic approach to the 
5 
6  litigation, and the burden that a piecemeal approach imposes on the government 
7 
and the courts, this Court should grant Defendants’ request for a temporary stay. 
8 
ARGUMENT 
9 
 
10  I.  PLAINTIFFS WILL NOT SUFFER HARDSHIP FROM A 
TEMPORARY STAY 
11 
Plaintiffs do not dispute that this case is in the early stages of litigation and 
12 
that any stay would likely be of a brief duration—likely a matter of weeks, not 
13 
months.  Courts have readily found that plaintiffs suffer no prejudice in similar 
14 
circumstances.  See Defs.’ Mot. at 6.   
15 
  Instead, Plaintiffs suggest that FOIA is different and that Plaintiffs will 
16 
suffer “significant prejudice[]” because a stay would delay the release of 
17 
responsive, non-exempt records by Defendants.  Pls.’ Opp’n at 9-10.  Contrary to 
18 
Plaintiffs’ suggestion, there is no reason that stays in FOIA cases should be treated 
19 
differently in this context.  Defendants are aware of two instances in which the 
20 
government sought centralization of FOIA actions by the JPML.  See Transfer 
21 
Mot. at 9-10.  In both, transferor courts granted motions to stay the proceedings 
22 
pending the JPML’s decision, and Defendants are not aware of any transferor court 
23 
in these actions that denied a stay motion.  See, e.g., Freedom Magazine v. IRS, 
24 
                                            
25 
where motion to remand was fully briefed by parties and was granted by court in 
26  same opinion as stay motion); Barber v. BP, PLC, No. 10-0263-WS-B, 2010 WL 
2266760, at *2 (S.D. Ala. June 4, 2010) (denying stay motion in putative class action 
27 
where district court had previously denied 23 “substantively identical motions to 
28 
stay” proceedings).    
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 3 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 5 of 10   Page ID #:261
 
1  No. 91-cv-6813 (S.D. Fla.) (ECF No. 10); Freedom Magazine v. IRS, No. 91-cv-
2  2921 (D. Md.) (ECF No. 6); Freedom Magazine v. IRS, No. 91-cv-12598 (D. 
3  Mass.) (ECF entry Feb. 7, 1992); Freedom Magazine v. IRS, No. 91-cv-704 (S.D. 
4  Ohio) (ECF No. 6); Bach v. IRS, No. 91-cv-20184 (N.D. Cal.) (ECF No. 
5  13); Chandler v. IRS, No. 91-cv-20183 (N.D. Cal.) (ECF No. 15); Kimmich v. IRS, 
6  No. 91-cv-20182 (N.D. Cal.) (ECF No. 13); Licciardi v. IRS, No. 91-cv-148 
7  (D.N.H.) (ECF No. 5).2  Plainly, then, stays pending JPML decisions are equally 
8  justified in FOIA cases. 
9  Moreover, notwithstanding their conclusory assertions of “delay,” Pls.’ 
10  Opp’n at 9, Plaintiffs fail to explain how a temporary stay would have any effect 
11  on the timing of the release of responsive records in this case.  Currently, 
12  Defendants’ response to the complaint is due June 29, 2017.  (ECF No. 17.)  
13  Briefing on Defendants’ motion to transfer has already been completed, and 
14  Defendants anticipate that their motion will be heard by the JPML on July 27, 2017 
15  and decided shortly thereafter.  As Defendants explained in their Motion, even if a 
16  stay is imposed, Defendants will continue to compile and review records during the 
17  pendency of the stay.  Defs.’ Mot. at 6.  Indeed, although Plaintiffs falsely state 
18  that “CBP has not notified Plaintiffs of a determination as to whether it will 
19  respond to the Request, nor . . . acknowledge ACLU’s request for an expedited 
20  response,” Pls.’ Opp’n at 4, Defendants in fact have granted Plaintiffs’ request for 
21 
                                            
22 
2 On June 6, 2017, the Western District of Washington denied Defendants’ 
23  motion to stay in one of the related actions.  See Order of June 6, 2017, ACLU of 
Washington v. DHS, No. 17-0562 (RSL) (ECF No. 20).  This Court is not bound by 
24 
that  decision  and  should  decline  to  follow  it,  as  it  ignores  many  of  the  key 
25  considerations justifying a stay here.  Contrary to that court’s decision, no delay in 
the production of documents will result from granting a stay because Defendants’ 
26 
processing of the ACLU affiliates’ FOIA requests is ongoing and will continue with 
27 
or without a stay.  See infra Pt. I. 
28 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 4 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 6 of 10   Page ID #:262
 
1  expedited treatment and have placed the coordinated requests of all the ACLU 
2  affiliates in the expedited processing queue, ahead of all non-expedited requests 
3  and later expedited requests.  Defendants have also released records responsive to 
4  one of the ACLU’s numerous requests and anticipates releasing more shortly, 
5  without any court order.  Thus, Plaintiffs are simply wrong that a temporary pause 
6  in the litigation will delay the release of records, see id. at 7-10, and Defendants’ 
7  response to Plaintiffs’ request will proceed on the same track with or without the 
8  stay.3 
9    Further, Plaintiffs do not identify anything that will occur in this Court 
10  before the JPML’s decision that would actually hasten the release of responsive 
11  documents.  Though Defendants will process Plaintiffs’ request “as soon as 
12  practicable,” 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(4), there is no reason to believe—particularly in 
13  light of the substantial volume of recent FOIA requests received by Defendants 
14  and the complexity of Plaintiffs’ request—that production of all responsive records 
15  will be complete by the time the JPML decides Defendants’ transfer motion.  
16  Indeed, Plaintiffs do not claim it would be, as they “have not yet asked the Court to 
17  set a [production] schedule” and believe that only “limited activity [is] likely to 
18  occur in this case before the MDL motion is decided.”  Pls.’ Opp’n at 12-13.  It is 
19  difficult to square these assertions with Plaintiffs’ dire warnings of unspecified 
20  “delay.”   
21   
   
22 
23 
                                            
24  3 Plaintiffs grasp at straws when they suggest that “CBP’s concern that the court 
might ‘set a schedule’” is a “tacit admission” that Defendants have not begun 
25 
processing Plaintiffs’ request.  Pls.’ Opp’n at 13.  As Defendants have already 
26  explained, they have granted Plaintiffs’ request for expedited processing, and CBP 
headquarters is currently in the process of compiling and reviewing records for 
27 
responsiveness to the FOIA requests in all of the related actions.  See supra Pt. I; 
28 
Defs.’ Mot. at 6.   
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 5 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 7 of 10   Page ID #:263
 
II.  SIMULTANEOUS AND DUPLICATIVE PROCEEDINGS IN 
1 
THIRTEEN PARALLEL ACTIONS WILL IMPOSE AN 
2 
UNNECESSARY BURDEN   
3  As Defendants explained, proceeding in this case (and the other related 
4  cases) while their motion to transfer is pending forces them to engage in 
5  simultaneous proceedings in thirteen separate cases before thirteen different courts.  
6  See Defs.’ Mot. at 5-6.  Plaintiffs disregard this burden as not a “real hardship” and 
7  claim that Defendants are only seeking to avoid “having to defend this action on a 
8  normal schedule.”  Pls.’ Opp’n at 10.   
9  Plaintiffs’ attempt to minimize the obvious burden to Defendants requires 
10  looking at this case in isolation from the other related actions.  But, as a direct 
11  result of the ACLU’s coordinated strategy to gerrymander these FOIA requests 
12  into thirteen separate cases, see Transfer Mot. at 4-8, Defendants must 
13  simultaneously answer complaints, appear in status conferences, confer with 
14  opposing counsel, and submit joint status reports in the thirteen related actions.  In 
15  this action in particular, Defendants would, at a minimum, be required to respond 
16  to the complaint, confer with Plaintiffs on initial disclosures and a discovery plan, 
17  and possibly to appear at a scheduling conference.  This work would be duplicated 
18  in the other related actions and in the transferee court, and “litigating essentially 
19  the same claims in courts all over the country is no doubt burdensome.”  Bd. of 
20  Trustees of Teachers’ Retirement Sys. of Illinois v. Worldcom, Inc., 244 F. Supp. 
21  2d 900, 905 (N.D. Ill. 2002); see also Virginia ex rel. Integra Rec LLC v. 
22  Countrywide Sec. Corp., No. 3:14CV706, 2015 WL 222312, at *3 (E.D. Va. Jan. 
23  14, 2015) (noting that defendant would suffer hardship “without a stay, including 
24  their ‘need to monitor and defend cases in multiple jurisdictions, on different 
25  schedules, when the cases may be consolidated to avoid that burden’” 
26  (quoting Wood v. Johnson & Johnson, No. WDQ-12-1572, 2012 WL 3240934, at 
27  *3 (D. Md. Aug. 3, 2012))) 
28  Plaintiffs’ suggestion that “answering the Complaint and conferring on a 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 6 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 8 of 10   Page ID #:264
 
1  joint discovery plan . . . would not be wasted effort even if this case were 
2  transferred by the JPML,” Pls.’ Opp’n at 14, is plainly wrong.  If the cases are 
3  consolidated, Defendants may not need to answer thirteen individual complaints at 
4  all, because the transferee court would likely require all of the ACLU affiliate 
5  plaintiffs to file a single amended consolidated complaint, which would require 
6  only one answer.  See, e.g., Manual for Complex Litigation § 20.132, at 224 n.668 
7  (4th ed. 2004).  And if the cases are transferred to Defendants’ proposed forum, 
8  this action would be exempt under the local rules from any requirement to engage 
9  in a Rule 16 conference or confer on a joint discovery plan.  See Transfer Mot. at 
10  15.  Thus, absent a stay, Defendants will be required to undertake time-consuming 
11  work—in as many as thirteen separate cases—that may otherwise prove 
12  unnecessary. 
13    Moreover, Plaintiffs do not disclaim any intent to request either discovery or 
14  a production schedule while Defendants’ transfer motion is pending.  See Pls.’ 
15  Opp’n at 14.  Any decision that this Court may reach on these issues clearly may 
16  conflict with those of other courts and/or the transferee court.  Defs.’ Mot. at 5-6.  
17  Any such inconsistency would be plainly prejudicial—it would likely place 
18  competing demands on the same agency personnel responsible for processing the 
19  responses to the requests in each of the related cases.  Id.  And, if Defendants’ 
20  motion to transfer is granted, Defendants would be forced to re-litigate these exact 
21  same issues before the transferee court.  Id.  Plaintiffs ignore this fact.  
22    Courts routinely find that the burden in time and expense from rearguing the 
23  same issues in different courts and the potential for inconsistent rulings justify a 
24  temporary stay pending a decision by the JPML on a motion to transfer.  See id. 
25  (collecting cases); Oregon ex rel. Kroger v. Johnson & Johnson, No. 11-CV-86-
26  AC, 2011 WL 1347069, at *6 (D. Or. Apr. 8, 2011); Paul v. Aviva Life & Ann. Co., 
27  No. 09-1038, 2009 WL 2244766, at *2 (N.D. Ill. July 27, 2009); Palmer v. Am. 
28  Honda Motor Co., No. CV 07-1904-PHX-DGC, 2008 WL 54914, at *1 (D. Ariz. 
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 7 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 24   Filed 06/12/17   Page 9 of 10   Page ID #:265
 
1  Jan. 3, 2008).  For those same reasons, a stay is warranted here as well. 
 
2 
III.  A STAY WOULD SERVE JUDICIAL ECONOMY BY AVOIDING 
3 
UNNECESSARY AND DUPLICATIVE PROCEEDINGS 
4  Plaintiffs also try to minimize the waste of judicial resources from 
5  duplicative proceedings in the related cases by arguing essentially that there are no 
6  duplicative proceedings because this action has nothing to do with the other related 
7  actions.  Pls.’ Opp’n at 13-14.  As discussed above, Plaintiffs are simply wrong.  In 
8  any event, Plaintiffs’ argument speaks more to whether transfer is appropriate than 
9  to whether this Court should stay proceedings while the JPML considers the 
10  appropriateness of transfer.  There can be no doubt that, if the case is transferred, 
11  any time this Court has devoted to pretrial proceedings will have been for naught.   
12  Finally, Plaintiffs suggest that a stay would be “premature” because they 
13  “have not yet asked the Court to set a schedule.”  Pls.’ Opp’n at 13.  As discussed, 
14  the imminent deadlines Defendants face in this and the twelve other related cases 
15  make Defendants’ stay motion anything but premature.  In any event, that 
16  Plaintiffs have not “yet” asked the Court to set a schedule does not mean Plaintiffs 
17  will not seek to do so before the JPML decides Defendants’ motion, or that they 
18  will not engage in other unnecessary proceedings.  A stay would make it 
19  unnecessary for the Court to devote its time to resolving any disputes over such 
20  pretrial matters. Cf. Rivers v. Walt Disney Co., 980 F. Supp. 1358, 1360 (C.D. Cal. 
21  1997) (granting stay in interests of judicial economy because absent stay “this 
22  Court will have needlessly expended its energies familiarizing itself with the 
23  intricacies of a case that would be heard by another judge”).  
24  CONCLUSION 
25    For the reasons set forth above and in Defendants’ Motion, this Court should 
26  grant Defendants’ request for a stay of proceedings.  
27   
28   
 
Defs.’ Reply in Support of Mot. to Stay Proceedings   - 8 -

11  response to its Freedom of Information Act (“FOIA”) request for records about an

E
Proceedings 
R 15   
T
 
T 16  A district court “should not automatically stay discovery, postpone rulings on   
H
G
I 17  pending motions, or generally suspend further rulings upon a [party’s] motion to the   
R
W
18  MDL Panel for transfer and consolidation.”  Rivers v. Walt Disney Co., 980 F. Supp.   
 
S
I
V 19  1358, 1360 (C.D. Cal. 1997); accord, Perry v. Luu, 2013 WL 3354446, at *3 (E.D.   
A
D
20  Cal. July 3, 2013).  Indeed, there is no requirement that a court stay litigation   
21  pending a JPML decision on a motion to transfer: such a motion “does not affect or   
22  suspend orders and pretrial proceedings in any pending federal district court action   
23  and does not limit the pretrial jurisdiction of that court.”  MDL Rule 2.1(d)   
24  (emphasis added); Litchfield Co., LLC v. BP, P.L.C., 2010 WL 2802498, at *1   
25  (D.S.C. July 14, 2010) (“A pending transfer motion before the MDL panel does not   
26  deprive the district court in which the action is then pending of jurisdiction over   
27  pretrial matters.”); Jozwiak v. Stryker Corp., 2010 WL 147143, *2 (M.D. Fla.   
28  Jan. 11, 2010).  Accordingly, courts have denied requests for stays under the

B.  A Stay Will Prejudice Plaintiffs By Delaying Access To Records Of 
1   
Significant Public Interest Amid An Ongoing Controversy. 
2   
The government’s requested stay would prejudice Plaintiffs because it would 
3   
undermine a central purpose of FOIA: ensuring records of public interest are 
4   
produced promptly to enable citizens to learn about government conduct and to act 
5   
on it at a time when public engagement would be effective.  This case is a textbook 
6   
example of the importance of timely disclosure, given the ongoing controversy and 
7   
debate about the Executive Orders.  See Compl. ¶¶ 5-11. 
8   
FOIA’s “core purpose is to inform citizens about what their government is up 
9   
to” so as to “ensure an informed citizenry,” which is “vital to the functioning of a 
10   
democratic society, needed to check against corruption and to hold the governors 
11   
 
P
L accountable to the governed.”  Yonemoto v. Dept. of Veteran’s Affairs, 686 F.3d 
12   
L
 
E
681, 687 (9th Cir. 2012), overruled in part on other grounds by Animal Legal Def. 
N 13   
I
A
Fund v. FDA, 836 F.3d 987 (9th Cir. 2016) (en banc).  Because “disclosure, not 
M 14   
E
R 15  secrecy, is the dominant objective of the Act,” the statute presumes all agency   
T
 
T records are public and places the burden on the government to justify withholding 
16   
H
G
based on specific exemptions that must be narrowly construed.  Id. at 687-88 
I 17   
R
W
(quotation omitted); see 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8)(A)(i) (presumption of openness). 
18   
 
S
I
V The statute recognizes the importance of prompt disclosure by requiring 
19   
A
D
agencies to respond to requests within 20 days, absent “unusual” or “exceptional” 
20   
circumstances.  5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i).  “[U]unreasonable delays in disclosing 
21   
non-exempt documents violate the intent and purpose of the FOIA, and the courts 
22   
have a duty to prevent these abuses.”  Long v. IRS, 693 F.2d 907, 910 (9th Cir. 
23   
1982).  Legislative history shows “Congress intentionally set harsh time limits for 
24   
agencies to respond to FOIA requests because it recognized that information is often 
25   
useful only if it is timely.”  Gilmore v. Dept’ of Energy, 33 F. Supp. 2d 1184, 1189 
26   
(N.D. Cal. 1998); see also Our Children’s Earth Found. v. Nat’l Marine Fisheries 
27   
Serv., 85 F. Supp. 3d 1074, 1089 (N.D. Cal. 2015) (“Congress was specifically 
28   
  7 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 14 of 22   Page ID #:204
     
1  concerned that agencies would delay in responding to requests”); Martins v. USCIS,   
2  962 F. Supp. 2d 1106, 1127 (N.D. Cal. 2013) (recognizing “expeditious release of   
3  documents…furthers FOIA’s core purpose of shed[ding] light on an agency’s   
4  performance”) (quotation omitted).     
5  Moreover, agencies must expedite processing and respond “as soon as   
6  practicable” where, as here, a requester shows “urgency to inform the public   
7  concerning actual or alleged Federal Government activity.”  Id. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i).    
8  “[E]xpedited processing of a FOIA request is a statutory right, not just a matter of   
9  court procedure.”  Edmonds v. FBI, 417 F.3d 1319, 1323 (D.C. Cir. 2005).  Courts   
10  consistently require expedited disclosure in cases like this one that involve requests   
11  for documents about matters that are subjects of intense media scrutiny and ongoing   
 
P
L
12  public debate.  For example, in EPIC v. DOJ, 416 F. Supp. 2d 30 (D.D.C. 2006), the   
L
 
E
N 13  court found that “given the great public and media attention that the government’s   
I
A
M 14  warrantless surveillance program has garnered and the recent hearings before the   
E
R 15  Senate Judiciary committee, the public interest is particularly well-served by the   
T
 
T
16  timely release of the requested documents.”  Id. at 42.  Likewise, in ACLU v. DOD,   
H
G
I 17  2006 WL 1469418 (N.D. Cal. May 25, 2006), the court held ACLU had an urgent   
R
W
18  need for records about a government program to gather information on political   
 
S
I
V
19  protesters because “[g]etting the requested information quickly might be valuable to   
A
D
20  would-be protesters and opposition groups” to “help them decide how to express   
21  their political viewpoints,” and, given the pending controversy over the program,   
22  delay also would harm “the media’s interest in quickly disseminating breaking,   
23  general-interest news.”  Id. at *7-8.  See also Gerstein v. CIA, 2006 WL 3462658, at   
24  *6 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 29, 2005) (expedited response appropriate where records   
25  concerned “an issue that is not only newsworthy, but was the subject of an ongoing   
26  national debate”).     
27  These principles apply here.  ACLU sought expedited processing of its FOIA   
28  request in order to provide the public with information about how the Los Angeles   
  8 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 15 of 22   Page ID #:205
     
1  CBP Field Office read and implemented the Executive Order.  Compl. ¶¶ 25-27.    
2  This has been, and continues to be, a hotly contested public issue.  Id.  ¶¶ 5-13.  As   
3  noted above and in the Complaint, the local implementation has resulted in mass   
4  protests (including demonstrations at Los Angeles and McCarran International   
5  Airports), widespread media coverage, calls for action by elected officials, and   
6  extensive litigation.  Id.  Although the Executive Order is on hold, the legal and   
7  public policy debate surrounding its initial enforcement remains very much alive,8   
8  and related litigation challenging the Orders remains pending in the Ninth Circuit.9     
9  Defendants’ request to delay this litigation is squarely at odds with FOIA’s   
10  purpose and ACLU’s statutory right to expedited access to the requested records.    
11  Moreover, Defendants fail to cite a single decision that delayed litigation about   
 
P
L
12  disclosure of public records in the midst of such an ongoing controversy.  See   
L
 
E
N 13  Motion at 3-6.  Their discussion of prejudice does not cite any FOIA cases, only   
I
A
M 14  readily distinguishable lawsuits involving private disputes where there was no   
E
R 15  showing of an imminent public interest in the dissemination of government   
T
 
T 16  information.10  ACLU, and the public, have an urgent need for the records at issue,   
H
G                                                  
RI 17  8 Indeed, President Trump has made public statements concerning the “Travel   
W Ban” as recently as the date of filing of this Opposition. Trump, Donald 
18   
S  (@realDonaldTrump), “People, the lawyers and the courts can call it whatever they 
I want, but I am calling it what we need and what it is, a TRAVEL BAN!”, 5 June 
V
19   
A 2017, 3:25 AM Tweet, available at https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/ 
D 871674214356484096; Trump, Donald (@realDonaldTrump), “The Justice Dept. 
20   
should have stayed with the original Travel Ban, not the watered down, politically 
correct version they submitted to S.C.”, 5 June 2017, 3:29 AM Tweet, available at 
21   
https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/871675245043888128.  
9 See, e.g., State of Hawaii, et al. v. Trump, Ninth Circuit No. 17-15589; cases 
22   
listed at Compl. ¶ 6.  Underscoring the public interest in this matter, the Ninth 
Circuit’s February 7, 2017 oral argument in State of Washington v. Trump has 
23   
drawn more than 140,000 views on YouTube.  See U.S. Court of Appeals for the 
Ninth Circuit, 17-35105, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RPOFowWqFGU.   
24  10 See Davis v. Pfizer, Inc., 2014 WL 1599005, *1 (N.D. Cal. Apr. 21, 2014)   
(products liability action); Freitas v. McKesson Corp., 2012 WL 161211, *2 (N.D. 
25   
Cal., Jan 10, 2012) (same); American Seafood, Inc. v. Magnolia Processing, Inc., 
1992 WL 102762, at *1 (E.D. Pa. May 7, 1992) (antitrust lawsuit against catfish 
26   
producer); Good v. Prudential Ins. Co. of Am., 5 F. Supp. 2d 804, 809 (N.D. Cal. 
1998) (fraud claim against insurer); Lange, 2013 WL 12153511 at *2 (products 
27   
liability); Rivers, 980 F. Supp. 1358, 1361 (racial discrimination class action); 
Siddighi, 2013 WL 12140988 (products liability); C.A. by Allen v. Pfizer, Inc., 2013 
28   
WL 6091766, at *1 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 19, 2013) (products liability action). 
  9 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 16 of 22   Page ID #:206
     
1  so that its members, media organizations, community groups, and ordinary citizens   
2  can have the information necessary to participate in the ongoing debate over the   
3  Orders at a time when they can still influence public policy.  See EPIC, 416 F. Supp.   
4  2d at 42.  Consequently, Plaintiffs would suffer significant prejudiced if the action is   
5  stayed.     
6   
C.  The Government Will Not Suffer Any Cognizable Hardship Absent A 
7  Stay   
8  In recognizing a court’s power to stay proceedings, the Supreme Court also   
9  cautioned that an applicant “for a stay must make out a clear case of hardship or   
10  inequity in being required to go forward, if there is even a fair possibility that the   
11  stay for which he prays will work damage to some one else.”  Landis v. N. Am. Co.,   
 
P
L
12  299 U.S. 248, 255 (1936) (emphasis added).  Applying this limiting principle, the   
L
 
E
N 13  Ninth Circuit will deny a stay where the moving party failed to make a clear   
I
A
M 14  showing of hardship: “To be sure…. if the stay is vacated [moving party] must   
E
R 15  proceed toward trial in the suit in the district court, but being required to defend a   
T
 
T
16  suit, without more, does not constitute a ‘clear case of hardship or inequity’ within   
H
G
I 17  the meaning of Landis.”  Lockyer v. Mirant Corp., 398 F.3d 1098, 1112 (9th Cir.   
R
W
18  2005).   
 
S
I
V
19  Here, Defendants fail to identify any real hardship they would suffer absent   
A
D
20  its proposed blanket stay, other than having to defend this action on a normal   
21  schedule.  See Motion at 5.  They vaguely speculate “moving forward could also   
22  result” in conflicting rulings.  Id. (emphasis added).  But Defendants do not identify   
23  these potential conflicts, or explain why they are likely, let alone imminent absent a   
24  stay.  They simply claim the agencies are also litigating requests for “identical or   
25  similar categories of records” from requesters other than Plaintiff.  Id. at 1.  This   
26  simply ignores that each of those other complaints has been brought by different   
27  plaintiffs and seeks different records.  As discussed above, in this case ACLU’s   
28  request seeks only locally-held records from the Los Angeles CBP Field Office, and   
  10 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 17 of 22   Page ID #:207
     
1  expressly excludes national or common records held at CBP Headquarters or   
2  elsewhere.  Compl. ¶¶ 3, 23; Compl. Ex. A at 10.  Thus, this case involves different   
3  factual and legal issues than the other pending actions.  The inquiry in this case will   
4  focus on the factual circumstances surrounding CBP’s local implementation of the   
5  Orders in the Los Angeles Field Office, and the reasonableness of the searches for   
6  records held in that office.  The other actions, by contrast, seek records about CBP’s   
7  implementation of the Orders in other CBP field offices, and as a result will raise the   
8  reasonableness of searches conducted for different records held in different   
9  locations.  It is impossible to know whether the lawsuits will raise any of the same   
10  claimed exemptions because each action seeks different records.    
11  Courts consistently reject stay requests founded on such mere conjecture.  For   
 
P
L
12  example, in Ramos v. Capital One, 2017 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 32368 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 7,   
L
 
E
N 13  2017), defendants claimed hardship from litigating related cases at the same time,   
I
A
M 14  but the court noted, “[a]side from conclusory assertions, Defendants have not   
E
R 15  provided any detail as to why simultaneous litigation of this case and [another] case   
T
 
T
16  that have substantial overlap in their factual and legal issues would cause a   
H
G
I 17  significant burden.”  Id. at *8-9.  Given the vague showing, the court concluded that   
R
W
18  any such hardships would “weigh only slightly in favor of granting the stay and do   
 
S
I
V
19  not outweigh the possible prejudice to Plaintiff.”  Id. at *12.  See also In re Maxwell   
A
D
20  Techs., Inc., 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 87955, at *5 (S.D. Cal. June 26, 2014) (denying   
21  stay litigation in light of related proceeding because moving party’s claim of   
22  hardship was “speculative”).11   
                                                 
23  11 The cases Defendants cite are readily distinguishable because they involved   
tort claims where there was little or no dispute over the common issues that posed a 
24   
serious risk of overlapping proceedings.  See Wilbanks v. Merck & Co., Inc., 2005 
WL 2234071, at *1 (W.D. Tenn. Sept. 13, 2005) (stay granted where cases from 
25   
same district raising similar jurisdictional issue had already been transferred to 
MDL panel and “hundreds, possibly thousands, of others that have been transferred 
26   
or are awaiting transfer in other districts”); Freitas, 2012 WL 161211 at *2 (judicial 
economy justified stay where “[o]ver 100 cases involving allegations of harm 
27   
resulting from the ingestion of medications containing” the same drug); Namovicz v. 
Cooper Tire & Rubber Co., 225 F. Supp. 2d 582, 583 n.2 (D. Md. 2001) (stay 
28   
granted where lawsuits were “filed on identical grounds seeking the same relief”); In 
  11 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002

1  The pendency of Defendant’s MDL motion does not change this analysis.    
2  For example, in Barber – a case on similar procedural footing to this one – the court   
3  denied a motion to stay as “premature” when it was brought one month prior to an   
4  MDL transfer decision.  The court found “the only tangible effect of entering a stay   
5  at this time would be to allow defendants a three-month reprieve after service of   
6  process before being required to answer the allegations brought by plaintiffs in the   
7  Complaint. Such a protracted delay appears both unnecessary and unwarranted.”    
8  Barber, 2010 WL 2266760, at *2.  Just as in this case, “there is no reason in the   
9  world why defendants cannot file responsive pleadings prior to the MDL’s   
10  determination on the pending transfer and consolidation issues,” because   
11  “[r]egardless of whether and where the MDL Panel ultimately transfers this action   
 
P
L
12  for consolidated and coordinated pretrial proceedings, defendants will need to file   
L
 
E
N 13  answers or responsive pleadings.”  Id.  Given the limited activity likely to occur in   
I
A
M 14  this case before the MDL motion is decided, Defendants cannot demonstrate any   
E
R 15  real harm justifying their proposed blanket stay.   
T
 
T
16  Because Plaintiffs have demonstrated far more than a “fair possibility” of   
H
G
I 17  prejudice and the government points to no hardship other than simply “being   
R
W
18  required to defend a suit,” its request should be denied.  Lockyer, 398 F.3d at 1112.   
 
S
I
V
19  D.  A Stay Will Not Significantly Promote Judicial Economy   
A
D
20  Defendants’ attempt to justify a blanket stay on grounds of judicial economy   
21  fail for reasons largely set forth above.  They argue, first, that stays are “typically”   
22  granted pending motions to transfer to the JPML.  Motion at 2.  This is overstated:   
23  as noted in Section A, courts frequently deny – and certainly do not automatically   
24  grant – requests for stays merely because a motion to transfer pretrial proceedings to   
25   
                                                                                                                                                                
re Musha Cay Litigation, 330 F. Supp. 2d 1364, 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (granting 
26   
unopposed request to consolidate arising “from the same underlying commercial 
transaction,” not addressing any stay request); In re Air Crash Near Kirksville, 
27   
Missouri, 383 F. Supp. 2d 1382, 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (same); C.A. by Allen, 2013 
WL 6091766 at *1 (noting it is “undisputed that this action involves common issues 
28   
with cases previously transferred” involving same pharmaceutical product). 
  12 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 19 of 22   Page ID #:209
     
1  the JPML is pending.  Defendants’ pending motion “does not affect” this Court’s   
2  pretrial jurisdiction.  MDL Rule 2.1(d).   
3  Next, Defendants argue a stay should be granted because the government “is   
4  coordinating [CBP’s] search for records responsive to all of the requests” filed by   
5  ACLU affiliates in this and other FOIA actions around the country.  Motion at 4.    
6  While Defendants are certainly free to coordinate their efforts from “CBP’s   
7  headquarters in Washington, DC,” id., doing so will not result in any particular   
8  judicial efficiencies.  Again, ACLU’s FOIA request in this case seeks records held   
9  by CBP employees in the Los Angeles Field Office, related to implementation of the   
10  Executive Order at Los Angeles International Airport, McCarran International   
11  Airport and the other ports of entry under that field office’s control; records held at   
 
P
L
12  “CBP Headquarters” were expressly excluded from the request at issue in this case.    
L
 
E
N 13  Compl. Ex. A, at p. 10.  Transfer thus will not obviate the need for Defendants to   
I
A
M 14  account in this litigation for the records held (or withheld) by CBP in Los Angeles   
E
R 15  or Nevada, or the search for such records conducted in the Los Angeles Field Office.    
T
 
T
16  The requested stay will serve only to delay that accounting, and the public’s access   
H
G
I 17  to these crucial records.   
R
W
18  It is telling that the only specific “inefficiency” Defendants identify is that   
 
S
I
V
19  “[a]bsent a stay, Plaintiffs may ask the Court to set a schedule for Defendants’   
A
D
20  search for, and potential release of, responsive information.”  Motion at 4.  This   
21  argument is problematic, for several reasons.  First, CBP’s concern that the court   
22  might “set a schedule” to begin searching for records is a tacit admission that   
23  Defendants have not yet done so – which would be a violation of their statutory   
24  obligation to process ACLU’s FOIA request promptly.  5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i),   
25  (E)(i).  A government agency should not be permitted to use a litigation stay to   
26  justify evasion of its basic FOIA obligations.  Second, Plaintiffs have not yet asked   
27  the Court to set a schedule; granting a stay on that basis would, at best, be   
28  premature.  Third, were the Court to set such a schedule, it would not be a waste of   
  13 
   
OPPOSITION TO DEFENDANTS’ MOTION TO STAY PROCEEDINGS 
Case No. 2:17-cv-2778 BRO (ASx) 
   
4835-7015-4313v.6 0201195-000002 
   

    
Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 20   Filed 06/05/17   Page 20 of 22   Page ID #:210
     
1  judicial resources because it would only affect the FOIA request at issue in this case   
2  – which, again, only applies to local records.   
3  Similarly, any other litigation activity likely to occur in this case before the   
4  MDL motion is decided – such as answering the Complaint and conferring on a joint   
5  discovery plan – would not be wasted effort even if this case were transferred by the   
6  JPML.  As noted above, these activities likely will impose little burden on the   
7  parties, and even less (if any) on this Court.  Given that the Court has not been asked   
8  to decide any motion (other than this one) or intervene in any discovery dispute   
9  (again, discovery has yet to begin), Defendants’ request for a blanket stay is patently   
10  overbroad.  In light of the prejudicial delay in public access that would result from a   
11  stay, and the absence of any meaningful efficiencies to be achieved, the stay sought   
 
P
L
12  by Defendants is unwarranted.   
L
 
E
N 13  IV.  CONCLUSION   
I
A
M 14  For all of the foregoing reasons, ACLU respectfully requests that the Court   
E
R 15  deny Defendants’ motion to stay the proceedings.

1  NOTICE OF MOTION AND MOTION TO DISMISS COMPLAINT 
2  TO THE COURT AND TO PLAINTIFF: 
3    PLEASE TAKE NOTICE that on June 26, 2017 at 1:30 p.m. or as soon 
4  thereafter as may be heard, Defendants the United States Department of Homeland 
5  Security (“DHS”) and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (“CBP”) will, and 
6  hereby do, move the Court for a temporary stay of further proceedings pending a 
7  decision by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (“JPML”) on Defendants’ 
8  motion to transfer this and other related actions for consolidated or coordinated 
9  proceedings pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1407.   
10  This motion is based on this notice of motion and motion, the attached 
11  memorandum of points and authorities, the records in this action, and such other

Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - ii - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 4 of 10   Page ID #:154
 
1  BACKGROUND 
2  This case is one of thirteen actions pending in thirteen different districts 
3  involving parallel Freedom of Information Act (“FOIA”) requests submitted by 
4  affiliates of the American Civil Liberties Union (“ACLU”) to CBP, a component 
5  of DHS.  Each FOIA request at issue asks CBP to search one of its field offices 
6  (and corresponding airports and/or ports of entry) for identical or similar categories 
7  of records about the implementation of Executive Order 13769, “Protecting the 
8  Nation from Terrorist Entry Into the United States,” 82 Fed. Reg. 8977 (Jan. 27, 
9  2017).   
10  The cases are ACLU of Northern California, et al. v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-
11  1970 (N.D. Cal. filed Apr. 10, 2017); ACLU of Virginia, et al. v. DHS, et al., No. 
12  17-cv-441 (E.D. Va. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Georgia, Inc., et al. v. DHS, et 
13  al., No. 17-cv-1309 (N.D. Ga. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Illinois, et al. v. DHS, 
14  et al., No. 17-cv-2768 (N.D. Ill. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Florida v. DHS, et 
15  al., No. 17-cv-21382 (S.D. Fla. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Maine, et al. v. 
16  CBP, et al., No. 17-cv-132 (D. Me. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Washington, et 
17  al. v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-562 (W.D. Wash. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of 
18  Arizona v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-1083 (D. Ariz. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of 
19  Southern California, et al. v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-2778 (C.D. Cal. filed Apr. 12, 
20  2017); ACLU of Oregon, et al. v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-575 (D. Or. filed Apr. 12, 
21  2017); ACLU of San Diego & Imperial Cnties. v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-733 (S.D. 
22  Cal. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU Found. of Texas, Inc. v. CBP, et al., No. 17-cv-
23  1128 (S.D. Tex. filed Apr. 12, 2017); ACLU of Michigan v. DHS, et al., No. 17-cv-
24  11149 (E.D. Mich. filed Apr. 12, 2017). 
25  On May 8, 2017, Defendants filed a motion with the JPML pursuant to 28 
26  U.S.C. § 1407 to transfer all of the ACLU affiliates’ pending FOIA cases relating 
27  to Executive Order 13769 to the United States District Court for the District of 
28  Columbia.  Copies of Defendants’ transfer motion, the supporting memorandum, 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 1 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 5 of 10   Page ID #:155
 
1  and the schedule of related actions have been served on the Clerk of this Court and 
2  are attached as exhibits to the Notice filed with this Court by Defendants on May 
3  8, 2017.  As explained more fully in Defendants’ memorandum in support of their 
4  transfer motion, the JPML previously has centralized multidistrict FOIA litigation 
5  in substantially similar circumstances, and transfer is likely here. 
6  Although the JPML has not yet scheduled a hearing on Defendants’ transfer 
7  motion, Defendants anticipate that the JPML will hear argument on the motion on 
8  July 27, 2017, and rule on the motion shortly thereafter.   
9  Defendants respectfully request that the Court temporarily stay proceedings in 
10  this action while the JPML considers Defendants’ motion to coordinate the 
11  handling of these cases.  This brief stay would relieve the parties and the judiciary 
12  of the burdens associated with duplicative pretrial proceedings in thirteen separate 
13  cases that raise identical or highly related issues, would prevent conflicting pretrial 
14  rulings, and would not prejudice Plaintiffs in this action.  Courts typically impose 
15  stays while motions are pending before the JPML, Rivers v. Walt Disney Co., 980 
16  F. Supp. 1358, 1362 (C.D. Cal. 1997), and for the reasons set forth, it is 
17  appropriate for this Court to do so here as well.   
18  ARGUMENT 
19    It is axiomatic that “the power to stay proceedings is incidental to the power 
20  inherent in every court to control the disposition of the causes on its docket with 
21  economy of time and effort for itself, for counsel and for litigants.”  Landis v. N. 
22  Am. Co., 299 U.S. 248, 254-55 (1936).  Courts routinely exercise their power to 
23  stay proceedings pending a decision on a motion before the JPML to transfer cases 
24  for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.  See Rivers, 980 F. Supp. at 
25  1362 (“[A] majority of courts have concluded that it is often appropriate to stay 
26  preliminary pretrial proceedings while a motion to transfer and consolidate is 
27  pending with the [JPML].”); see also Cooper v. Siddighi, No. EDCV 13-00345 
28  JGB (SPx), 2013 WL 12140988, at *4 (C.D. Cal. May 8, 2013) (collecting 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 2 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 6 of 10   Page ID #:156
 
1  cases); Good v. Prudential Ins. Co. of Am., 5 F. Supp. 2d 804, 809 (N.D. Cal. 
2  1998) (courts “frequently grant stays pending a decision by the [JPML]”); see also 
3  David F. Herr, “Multidistrict Litigation Manual:  Practicing Before the Judicial 
4  Panel on Multidistrict Litigation” § 3:15 at 32 (“District courts . . . readily stay[] 
5  proceedings pending a Panel decision.”). 
6    Courts look to several factors when determining whether to issue a stay of 
7  proceedings pending the JPML’s decision, including whether judicial economy 
8  would be served by avoiding duplicative litigation, the burden on the moving party 
9  if the action is not stayed, and any potential prejudice to the non-moving party.  
10  See Rivers, 980 F. Supp. at 1360; see also Douglas v. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., 
11  No. 13-cv-2331, 2013 WL 4013901, at *1 (N.D. Cal. Aug. 5, 2013).  A stay of 
12  proceedings, for the sole purpose and duration necessary for the JPML to decide 
13  Defendants’ motion, satisfies each of these factors. 
 
14 
A.  Judicial Economy Requires a Stay Pending a Decision by the 
15  JPML 
16  Staying the proceedings in this action would further judicial economy by 
17  avoiding the need for multiple courts to deal with the same or similar pretrial 
18  issues.  Courts typically grant temporary stays pending motions to transfer to the 
19  JPML where, like here, doing so would relieve the parties and the courts from 
20  engaging in simultaneous and duplicative pretrial proceedings.  See Rivers, 980 F. 
21  Supp. at 1360 (stay warranted in interest of judicial economy to ensure court from 
22  “needlessly expend[ing] its energies familiarizing itself with the intricacies of a 
23  case that would be heard by another judge”); Freitas v. McKesson Corp., No. C 
24  11-05967, 2012 WL 161211, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 10, 2012) (“[G]ranting a stay in 
25  this case would prevent the Court from needlessly duplicating work that will be 
26  done by the MDL transferee court . . . .”); Naegele v. Albers, 355 F. Supp. 2d 129, 
27  141 (D.D.C. 2005) (stating that “litigating essentially the same issues in two 
28  separate forums is not in the interest of judicial economy or in the parties’ best 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 3 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 7 of 10   Page ID #:157
 
1  interests”). 
2  The thirteen related cases involve parallel FOIA requests, each of which seeks 
3  disclosure of similar or identical categories of records related to the 
4  implementation of Executive Order 13769 from different CBP field offices.  To 
5  ensure consistency in responding to the ACLU affiliates’ FOIA requests, CBP’s 
6  headquarters in Washington, DC is coordinating the agency’s search for records 
7  responsive to all of the requests at issue in the related actions, as well as its 
8  processing of responsive records for potential release.  Absent a stay, Plaintiffs 
9  may ask the Court to set a schedule for Defendants’ search for, and potential 
10  release of, responsive information.  Particularly because the ACLU affiliates have 
11  been coordinating their handling of these lawsuits, any pretrial proceedings 
12  regarding the production schedule would likely duplicate those before other courts 
13  in the related actions, and, if the JPML grants Defendants’ motion to transfer, any 
14  ruling by the Court could ultimately be vitiated by the transferee court. 
15  Given the early stage of the case and the status of Defendants’ processing of 
16  the ACLU affiliates’ FOIA requests, it is unlikely that any issues regarding the 
17  adequacy of CBP’s search, the appropriateness of CBP’s withholding of responsive 
18  information pursuant to the FOIA’s statutory exemptions, or the need for discovery 
19  will ripen for the Court’s consideration before the JMPL rules on Defendants’ 
20  transfer motion.  Nevertheless, were any of these issues to arise, they would 
21  substantially overlap in each of the related actions.  In a typical FOIA action, the 
22  defendant agency establishes its compliance with the requirements of the FOIA 
23  through declarations that set forth the procedures the agency followed in 
24  conducting its search and the basses for withholding responsive records.  See, 
25  e.g., Perry v. Block, 684 F.2d 121, 126 (D.C. Cir. 1982) (per curiam).  And 
26  although discovery is rare in FOIA cases, even when granted, it “is generally 
27  limited to the scope of the agency’s search and its indexing and classification 
28  procedures.”  Heily v. Dep’t of Commerce, 69 F. App’x 171, 174 (4th Cir. 2003) 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 4 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 8 of 10   Page ID #:158
 
1  (per curiam).  Thus, because CBP headquarters is coordinating the responses to the 
2  ACLU affiliates’ FOIA requests, any pretrial proceedings that could arise in this 
3  Court regarding the adequacy of the agency’s searches, the application of the 
4  FOIA’s statutory exemptions, or requests for discovery would be duplicative in 
5  each of the related actions.  A temporary stay would avoid this needless use of 
6  judicial resources. 
7  B.  A Stay Is Necessary to Avoid Hardship to Defendants 
8  Moving forward with the proceedings in this case would not only frustrate 
9  judicial economy, it would also prejudice Defendants.  Defendants would be 
10  required to engage in simultaneous and duplicative pretrial practice, including 
11  responding to thirteen separate complaints that are materially identical.  
12  See Cooper, 2013 WL 12140988, at *4 (defendant would suffer “significant 
13  hardship” if “various plaintiffs are allowed to proceed against [it] in different 
14  forums” and “force[ defendant] to re-argue the same issues”); Wilbanks v. Merck & 
15  Co., No. 05-1241, 2005 WL 2234071, at *2 (W.D. Tenn. Sept. 13, 2005) (granting 
16  stay and stating that “in absence of a stay, the risk to [defendant] of duplicative 
17  motions and discovery is significant”). 
18  Moreover, moving forward could also result in rulings on pretrial issues that 
19  conflict with those of other districts or of the transferee court if the JPML grants 
20  the transfer motion.  See C.A. ex rel. Allen v. Pfizer, Inc., No. C 13-4087, 2013 WL 
21  6091766, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 19, 2013) (recognizing that absent stay, defendants 
22  may be required to relitigate issues decided by transferor court before MDL 
23  panel); Namovicz v. Cooper Tire & Rubber Co., 225 F. Supp. 2d 582, 585 (D. Md. 
24  2001) (staying proceedings pending decision by JPML to consolidate cases 
25  because it is “necessary to ensure that, in the event consolidation of all cases for 
26  pre-trial is ordered, there is consistent treatment of the numerous lawsuits”).  If 
27  proceedings are stayed and the transfer motion is granted, the transferee court 
28  would be able to set an efficient pretrial process that establishes a single production 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 5 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 9 of 10   Page ID #:159
 
1  schedule (if necessary), avoids duplicative work and competing demands on the 
2  same agency personnel, and “conserves the resources of the parties, their counsel 
3  and the judiciary.”  In re Musha Cay Litig., 330 F. Supp. 2d 1364, 1365 (J.P.M.L. 
4  2004); see also In re Air Crash Near Kirksville, Mo., 383 F. Supp. 2d 1382, 1383 
5  (J.P.M.L. 2005).  
6  C.  Plaintiffs Would Not Be Prejudiced by the Stay 
7  Plaintiffs would not be prejudiced by the limited stay that Defendants have 
8  requested.  This action is in the early stages of litigation, and Defendants have not 
9  yet responded to the Complaint.  See Davis v. Pfizer, Inc., No. C 14-1204, 2014 
10  WL 1599005, at *1 (N.D. Cal. Apr. 21, 2014) (finding no prejudice to plaintiff 
11  where the case was in the “very early procedural stage”).  Defendants anticipate 
12  that the JPML will hold argument on Defendants’ motion on July 27, 2017 and will 
13  rule on it shortly thereafter, and therefore the stay would likely be of limited 
14  duration.  See Hearing Information, United States Judicial Panel on Multidistrict 
15  Litigation, available at http://www.jpml.uscourts.gov/hearing-information.  
16  See Lange v. Mentor Worldwide LLC, No. CV 13-6287 JGB (SPx), 2013 WL 
17  12153511, at *2 (C.D. Cal. Oct. 15, 2013) (holding that prejudice to plaintiffs was 
18  “minimal since the MDL is proceeding swiftly on the decision to transfer and 
19  Plaintiffs’ case will not idle on the MDL’s docket (quotation marks 
20  omitted)); Seafood, Inc. v. Magnolia Processing, Inc., Civ. Nos. 92-1030, 92-1086, 
21  1992 WL 102762, at *1 (E.D. Pa. May 7, 1992) (holding plaintiffs would not be 
22  prejudiced where the stay “will only be in effect until the JPML issues its 
23  decision[, and t]herefore, there will be no extended delay”).   
24  Furthermore, Defendants are still in the process of compiling records 
25  responsive to the FOIA requests in the related actions.  Defendants will continue to 
26  compile and review records during the pendency of any stay.  As a result, a 
27  temporary stay until the JPML renders its decision should not significantly delay 
28  the eventual release of responsive records to the public. 
 
Defs.’ Mot. to Stay Proceedings     - 6 - 

Case 2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS   Document 18   Filed 05/17/17   Page 10 of 10   Page ID #:160
 
1   
2  CONCLUSION 
3    For the reasons set forth above, this Court should grant Defendants’ request 
4  for a stay of proceedings.  
5  Dated: May 17, 2017      Respectfully submitted,

documents.text:
Case 2:17-cvC-0a2s7e7 M8-DBLR NOo-A. 2S7  8 D6 o  cDuomceunmt e2n8t   8 F8i l e Fdi l0e8d/ 0038//1072 / 1 P7a  g Pea 1g eo f1 5 o  f  P5age ID #:287
FILED
CLERK, U.S. DISTRICTCOURT
UNITED STATES JUDICIAL PANEL 
88//33//22001177
on 
MULTIDISTRICT LITIGATION
CENTRAL DISTRICTOF CALIFORNIA
DDDD
BY: ___________________ DEPUTY
IN RE: AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION 
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT (FOIA) REQUESTS
REGARDING EXECUTIVE ORDER 13769 MDL No. 2786
2:17-cv-02778-BRO-AS
American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California et al v. U.S. Department of Homeland Security et al
ORDER DENYING TRANSFER
Before the Panel:* Defendants, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and U.S.
Customs and Border Protection (CBP),1 move to centralize thirteen Freedom of Information Act
(FOIA) actions in the District of District of Columbia.  The actions, which are pending in thirteen
districts, are listed on the attached Schedule A.
Plaintiffs, which are various affiliates of the American Civil Liberties Union, oppose
centralization.  If the Panel grants the Section 1407 motion over their objections, plaintiffs ask that
the action in the Eastern District of Michigan be excluded, and that the litigation be centralized in
the Eastern District of Virginia or, alternatively, in the District of Maine or the Western District of
Washington.   
On the basis of the papers filed and the hearing session held, we deny Defendants’ motion. 
The actions arguably share a limited number of factual issues arising out of FOIA requests made by
plaintiffs for records concerning CBP’s interpretation and implementation – at local international
airports and, in the Eastern District of Michigan case, U.S./Canada border crossings – of the January
27, 2017, Executive Order No. 13769, titled “Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry
Into the United States,” as well as any judicial order or executive directive issued regarding the
Executive Order.  But these factual issues, which principally concern the adequacy of CBP’s
searches for the requested records, as well as CBP’s coordination of the searches by its Washington,
D.C., headquarters, appear relatively straightforward and unlikely to entail extensive pretrial
proceedings. See Riccardi v. U.S. Dep’t of Justice, 32 F. Supp. 3d 59, 63 (D.D.C. 2014) (“In a FOIA
case, where the adequacy of an agency’s search is questioned, the Court may grant summary
judgment based on information provided in ‘[a] reasonably detailed affidavit, setting forth the search
terms and the type of search performed, and averring that all files likely to contain responsive
materials (if such records exist) were searched.’”) (quoting Valencia–Lucena v. U.S. Coast Guard,
180 F.3d 321, 326 (D.C. Cir.1999)).  Indeed, as Defendants acknowledge, these actions probably will
not involve any discovery.  See Mem. in Supp. of Defs.’ Mot. for Transfer, at 16 n.8 (ECF No. 1-1)
*  Judge Marjorie O. Rendell took no part in the decision of this matter.
1  CBP is a component of DHS.

Case 2:17-cvC-0a2s7e7 M8-DBLR NOo-A. 2S7  8 D6 o  cDuomceunmt e2n8t   8 F8i l e Fdi l0e8d/ 0038//1072 / 1 P7a  g Pea 2g eo f2 5 o  f  P5age ID #:288
-2-
(“In the unlikely event that discovery is authorized in these Related Actions, Defendants anticipate
that CBP witnesses would be located in Washington, DC, while Plaintiffs would not have any
witnesses of their own.”); see also, e.g., Justice v. I.R.S., 798 F. Supp. 2d 43, 47 (D.D.C. 2011)
(noting that in FOIA actions, discovery is “disfavored”).2
Defendants also contend that common factual questions will inform any review of CBP’s
determinations to withhold information from disclosure pursuant to FOIA’s statutory exemptions.
This argument is unconvincing, because the application of those exemptions is a legal issue.  See,
e.g., Trentadue v. Integrity Comm., 501 F.3d 1215, 1226 (10th Cir. 2007) (“Whether a FOIA
exemption justifies withholding a record is a question of law that we review de novo.”); see also Am.
Mgmt. Servs., LLC v. Dep’t of the Army, 703 F.3d 724, 729 (4th Cir. 2013) (same).
Although defendants heavily rely on the Panel’s 1992 decision in MDL No. 910, In re:
Freedom Magazine/Internal Revenue Service FOIA Litigation, and its 1991 decision in MDL No.
892, In re: Church of Scientology Flag Service Organization/Internal Revenue Service FOIA
Litigation, those decisions are in at least some tension with more recent Panel precedent.  E.g., In
re: Clean Water Rule: Definition of “Waters of the United States,” 140 F. Supp. 3d 1340, 1341
(J.P.M.L. 2015) (denying federal government defendants’ motion for centralization of nine actions
pending in seven districts involving challenges to EPA rule, where resolution of the actions would
“involve only very limited pretrial proceedings,” and discovery, if any, would be “minimal”). 
Moreover, the decisions are distinguishable.  In Freedom Magazine, the eight cases were filed by
a single plaintiff, which specifically sought records located at the IRS’s  Washington, D.C.
headquarters.  See Freedom Magazine Transfer Order at 2 (J.P.M.L. Feb. 12, 1992) (unpublished). 
And, in Church of Scientology, “every FOIA request in the litigation was made upon the IRS office
in Jacksonville in [the Middle District of Florida, where the cases were centralized],” and related
litigation was pending in that district.  See Church of Scientology Transfer Order at 2 (J.P.M.L.. Sept.
4, 1991) (unpublished).  Here, the actions are brought by separate plaintiffs (albeit all ACLU
affiliates), and each FOIA request targets a different CBP field office.
Defendants also argue that centralization would reduce litigation costs.  They represent,
without contradiction, that it was unnecessary for the ACLU plaintiffs to submit a separate FOIA
request for each CBP field office, and that the national ACLU, or the various affiliates acting
together, simply could have sent CBP headquarters a single FOIA request asking the agency to
search the same field offices for the same records covered by the multiple requests.  But, the
potential for litigation cost savings, without more, does not warrant centralization, particularly
where, as here, there is little likelihood of complex pretrial proceedings.
2  In the unlikely event that these cases actually involve a significant amount of duplicative
pretrial discovery, Defendants are free to file another motion for centralization.

Case 2:17-cvC-0a2s7e7 M8-DBLR NOo-A. 2S7  8 D6 o  cDuomceunmt e2n8t   8 F8i l e Fdi l0e8d/ 0038//1072 / 1 P7a  g Pea 3g eo f3 5 o  f  P5age ID #:289
-3-
IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED that the motion for centralization of these actions is denied.
 PANEL ON MULTIDISTRICT LITIGATION
                                                                             
    Sarah S. Vance
             Chair
Charles R. Breyer Lewis A. Kaplan
Ellen Segal Huvelle R. David Proctor
Catherine D. Perry
